fields.description:
I was evaluating bamboo 4.2.1 and during the setup process I get a ClassCastException.  In researching the problem it seems very similar to JIRA issue CONF-20793.  The workaround is the same, downgrade tomcat to 6.0.26.

Java Exception:
org.springframework.dao.InvalidDataAccessApiUsageException: OracleLobCreator needs to work on [oracle.jdbc.OracleConnection], not on [org.apache.tomcat.dbcp.dbcp.PoolableConnection]: specify a corresponding NativeJdbcExtractor; nested exception is java.lang.ClassCastException: org.apache.tomcat.dbcp.dbcp.PoolableConnection cannot be cast to oracle.jdbc.OracleConnection
Caused by: java.lang.ClassCastException: org.apache.tomcat.dbcp.dbcp.PoolableConnection cannot be cast to oracle.jdbc.OracleConnection
fields.summary: ClassCastException when using Bamboo and JNDI Datasource with Oracle DB

fields.description:
[~nmuldoon], [~pbruski] this is for puppet adoption.

bamboo-cfg.xml, which stores the database configuration, also has volatile data for the Bamboo build number level.  It also has the licensing information and checksums.

This information should be placed into the database, like JIRA and Stash do, instead.  If you can't do that then can there be two property files made out of {{bamboo-cfg.xml}} where one is volatile, and would not be under Puppet control, and the other be static and consisting of the database and hibernate configuration?

Thanks!

ps...hello! :)
fields.summary: bamboo-cfg.xml should not contain volatile data like the bamboo build number and licensing information

fields.description:
When you unpack atlassian-bamboo-$version.tar.gz the contents are unpacked to a directory called "Bamboo"

This is inconsistent with all the other Atlassian products and also can cause problems for upgrades, wiping out your existing install and config if you aren't careful.

The directory name should be on the order of "atlassian-bamboo-4.2" for example.   You can change this in your maven assembly xml and the assembly plugin declaration.

[~nmuldoon], [~pbruski] this is also for puppet adoption
fields.summary: Atlassian downloadable packages should unpack with atlassian-bamboo-$version instead of a directory called Bamboo
Create an HVM-based image for use with instances requiring HVM

fields.description:
The Bamboo Clover Plugin calls Clover by maven-clover2-plugin. This plugin generates two files during build in ${java.io.tmpdir} directory. One is clover_fs_rez*txt and the second one is grover*.jar. A bugfix for first file has been implemented in Clover 3.1.7 version. A bugfix for second file is scheduled for Clover 3.1.8. 

As soon as maven-clover2-plugin:3.1.8 is released, the Bamboo Clover Plugin must be extended in such way that it will have two extra options for the Misc tab / Clover section / Automatic clover integration:
 * checkbox "Skip Groovy instrumentation and don't create grover.jar artifact"
 * text field (file path) "Create groovy.jar artifact in"

If checkbox is enabled, then it shall pass -Dmaven.clover.skipGroverJar=true property for build. 
If text field is not empty (trim whitespaces) then pass -Dmaven.clover.groverJar=<path> for build.

Checkbox/text field shall be greyed out or hidden if user selects "manual integration" radio button. 
Text field shall be greyed out/hidden if checkbox is enabled.
fields.summary: Perform cleanup of clover_fs_rez* and grover*jar files by Bamboo Clover Plugin

fields.description:
There are several EC2 instance types that aren't supported by Elastic Bamboo, including the very highest performance instance types, which are great when you want to throw money at a build to make it go faster.

The list I see in the drop down in Bamboo 4.1 OnDemand is missing the following instance types:

Medium (m1.medium)
Cluster Compute Eight Extra Large (cc2.8xlarge)
High I/O Quadruple Extra Large (hi1.4xlarge)

The last two especially seem important, as they provide a way to pay for more performance that you can't get with any other instance types. (Users who need medium can pay for large, and spot prices aren't that different right now.)
fields.summary: Add new instance types to Elastic Bamboo

fields.description:
Please simplify and make [this Bamboo upgrade procedure|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+generic+upgrade+guide] more precise. I edited Step 5 a bit for now.

Let's specify that there are 2 options to upgrade Bamboo:

1. Using Export/Import (or pointing to the exported .zip file during the setup wizard)
2. Install a new Bamboo (the version to which the old one gets upgraded to) with a new DB (external or embedded HSQL). Point the newly installed <Bamboo-install>/webapp/WEB-INF/classes/bamboo-init.properties to the old BAMBOO_HOME (which already contains link to the old DB).

We need to make that page as short as possible so that our customers not get scared or lost and not complain about the sophistication of the upgrade process. Please let me know if you need more information on this.

Cheers,
Armen
fields.summary: Simplify the Bamboo upgrade documentation

fields.description:
We mostly use bamboo for the normal use case of CI/CD.  But for two rather critical applications we are using a bit differently - automated availabuiltiy testing.

Every 5 minutes a scheduled build runs the latest soapUI tests against the environment to ensure all is healthy.

After running for a few months we are up to 38,000+ builds.

This is not a problem on the overall server, but when it comes to viewing that plan (summary, configuration, etc) there are a few kinks.

a) incredibly slow to load any page related to that plan. (I suspect due to stat building or something akin)
b) Inaccurate stats.  The Plan Statistics summary says "10000 Builds" even though we are far past that.
fields.summary: Handle 10,000+ builds in bamboo

fields.description:
Since we upgrade to Bamboo 4.1.2, some of our users have been complaining about the lack of visibility into the plan configuration. Specifically, the removal of the read-only view of the plan configuration. This was extremely useful to view the parent/child relationship. In most servers, editing the config to do the same thing would probably suffice.
However, our primary Bamboo server has the following metrics:
{noformat}
Instance Statistics
Number of plans 4898
Number of builds (approx)915589
Full reindex time (approx)8 hours, 28 mi
{noformat}

In Bamboo 4.1.2, when you edit a plan config to alter dependencies, it's page after page of plans and buried in there is whatever dependencies you may have already established.
The old read-only configuration tab on the plan summary presented those existing dependencies in a concise manner.

Something needs to be done to improve the plan dependency management experience in the UI for instances with large numbers of plans.

Some suggestions off the top of my head are:

# Move any existing parent/child dependencies right to the top of the tab in a new "Existing dependencies" section, so they're easy to see and change
# Introduce some filter box to the dependency tab so that users can filter plans by entering text

Above all else, we'd like to see a read-only configuration re-introduced somewhere the plan, so we don't have to edit a plan to know what the configuration is. I'm attaching a screen grab showing what a nightmare dependency management currently is.
fields.summary: Bamboo UI is inadequate to deal with parent/child dependencies where there are a large number of plans

fields.description:
Currently, the order presented on the UI for Jobs inside Stages is not respected by Bamboo. Since Jobs run in parallel, as soon as an Agent with the necessary capabilities is made available, the Job (independently from its order in the list) is run.

However there are situations when it would be good to be able to fix an order to the Job run.

Example: *Build Speed*
Job A takes 30 minutes; Job B takes 60 minutes.

If Job A starts, and then 20 minutes later an Agent becomes available and Job B starts, the total run time of the Stage would be 80 minutes (wait time plus the longer running second Job)

If the 60 minute Job started with the first available Agent and still the 20 minute wait time for the second Agent happens, the total run time of the stage would be 60 minutes (even with the 20 min delay, Job A would still finish before Job B). 

By running the slowest Job first will allow the Stage to "attempt" to run its Jobs in the shorter time frame possible.

So, by allowing Users to define an order for the Jobs would allow them to try to adapt their Stages to run faster.

*PLUS:* maybe, Bamboo could detect how long a build takes (after the first time it is run) and then automatically arrange the Jobs' order so that they can run in the shortest time frame possible. This would be amazing :-)
fields.summary: Allow Jobs to have a fixed order in a Stage

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently the only way to authenticate with Bamboo's REST API is by using user credentials or via an OAuth client. It would also be beneficial to be able to expose a build specific environment variable with a token so that a Bamboo build can also authenticate via that token.

h3. Suggested Solution
* Token based access similar to Bitbucket's personal access tokens:
** [Personal access tokens|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/personal-access-tokens-939515499.html]
* Bamboo environment variable containing a token per build for API access within a build.
fields.summary: Provide token based access to Bamboos REST API

I ran against an issue with my plugin (https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/be.sofico.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-svntoolkit-plugin) after updating to Bamboo 4.2.

Because of the SVNKit update included in that release an issue popped up in the SVNKit library which causes the SVN Diff to malfunction partially.

The issue was fixed and will be included in the next SVNKit release. Details about the case can be found in this thread: http://subversion.1072662.n5.nabble.com/Changes-to-the-output-of-diff-after-upgrade-to-1-7-4-v1-td1307.html

I was wondering if this new SVNKit version could be included in the next Bamboo release once it comes out (I am assuming that it will be 1.7.6 but am still waiting for confirmation from the developer).

thanks
jan

fields.description:
4.2 adds support for SVN 1.7, but the default checkout is still 1.6 for backwards compatibility.

You need to add a system flag {{-Dbamboo.svn.wc.format=1.7}} to enable this. It would be nice to make this more easily configurable in the UI



--- Original Description


After letting Bamboo perform a new checkout, the checkout structure will contain a {{.svn}} folder in every single directory, (Subversion 1.6 format), rather than a single {{.svn}} folder at the root (Subversion 1.7 format).

Also, the SVN "entries" files that lives in each of the .svn folders have a first line populated by "10". This reflects the format version 10 which relates to 1.6 format, while 1.7 format should show a "12" in the single "entries" file that lives in it's single {{.svn}} folder.

This happens because Bamboo uses SVNKit v1.3.x, which supports Subversion working copies <= 1.6 ([read more|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/Troubleshooting+Subversion]), instead of a Native Subversion Client, so if you upgrade the Subversion server from 1.6 to 1.7 it will still checkout as 1.6.

A workaround for this problem is to add the following extra parameter to the {{<BAMBOO_INSTALL>/config/wrapper.conf}} file:
{noformat}
wrapper.java.additional.X=-Dbamboo.svn.wc.format=1.7
{noformat}
Where {{"X"}} is the next number of the {{"wrapper.java.additional"}} section of the file.

If a Remote Agent is being used, there are two options:
* Start the agent from command line using the {{"-Dbamboo.svn.wc.format=1.7"}} parameter
* Add the same line above to the {{wrapper.conf}} in the Remote Agent's home folder
fields.summary: Allow users to easily update the default SVN checkout to 1.7

fields.description:
We have identified and fixed a vulnerability caused by the way WebWorks/Struts and Freemarker templates are used in Bamboo. 

The vulnerability allows a non-authenticated user to execute arbitrary Java methods in the JVM hosting the Bamboo application. This can be used to execute OS commands as the JVM user.

All versions of Bamboo up to and including 4.0.1 are affected. 

Full details are available in the advisory at https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+Security+Advisory+2012-08-28
fields.summary: OGNL injection vulnerability

fields.description:
When a remote agent is on a DHCP network, everytime the IP changes, the remote agent needs to revalidate itself because the token used to authenticate the agents is based on IP and a change in IP will trigger a change.

One thing that can be done in this case is to set the IP address of the remote agent to be static, but this is not possible to some companies.

Maybe this approval on IP change can be automated someway?

The only concern is if this process is automated, then the whole idea of the remote agent authentication will be defeated as attackers can inject scripts to authenticate malicious agents. This is why we made it manual for the administrators to review before approving.

Is this something that can be implemented?
fields.summary: Improve the way Remote Agents work in DHCP networks

fields.description: Possible a defaultin the UI if no setting is found?
fields.summary: Restricted Admin Setting shows as selected when its not

fields.description:
When releasing from a Greenhopper board, it should be possible to run a release build to release the version.

The only way todo this from JIRA at the moment is using the ['Build and Release' version functionality|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Running+a+Bamboo+Build+when+Releasing+a+Version].
fields.summary: Build and release from Greenhopper

fields.description:
Did we, at some point prevent, people from being able to access .ftl files directly?  
This information need to get moved to CAC and use the new help links.
fields.summary: Working Directory help bubble gives page not found

fields.description:
Scenario.  
# Base URL In Bamboo set to something incorrect
# Create app link from e.g. JIRA to Bamboo, feature dont work because url is wrong
# Change Base URL to be correct
# Delete and readd app link (There is an applinks bug raised for why this bit is necessary)

I haven't actually tried to reproduce it a second time.  But this is how it happened the first time..

It shows up what is the parent( if any) and what is the child plan gets kicked for this plan. If you click on the Plan name, it takes you to the dependencies of that particular plan. This tab used show only the parent and child of that particular plan not a whole list."

Do you have plans of changing this back to what it was?

fields.description: If we are using a git super-project composed of submodules (or a hg super-project composed of subrepositories), we would like to see on Build Summary/Code Changes all changesets since last build from the submodule repositories too. Similarly like Bamboo do with svn:externals.
fields.summary: Collect and display changes in the submodules (git) and subrepositories (hg) like svn:externals.

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce: (checked on 4.1.2 but I expect it still persist on 4.2++)

1) Create a plan with a Job.
2) edit Job's Miscellaneous configuration page
3) tick "Override default hanging build detection criteria"
4) note the "Build Queue Timeout" is empty (good! buildConfiguration for that job doesn't contain "custom.buildHangingConfig.minutesQueueTimeout" property as expected)
5) set "Build Queue Timeout" to something, i.e. "60". (Set the rest of fields so validation doesn't interfere)
6) save
7) note the "custom.buildHangingConfig.minutesQueueTimeout" property for that job will be set to "60" as expected
8) untick the "Override default hanging build detection criteria"
9) save
10a) the "custom.buildHangingConfig.minutesQueueTimeout" property will still be available in that job and will hold "60" as value - that's not expected
10b) instead I'd expect this property to be wiped out completely from configuration.
10c) if you tick the "Override default hanging build detection criteria" you will notice the "60" is still visible in the UI.
fields.summary: Disabling overriding of "default hanging build detection criteria" in a Job miscellaneous tab is ignored by Bamboo.

fields.description: I think that the branches in this window are listed in alphabetical order, but 90% of the time, the branch build I want to create is for one where I've just committed. Could this list the branches based on the timestamp of the latest commit on the branch in reverse chronological order?
fields.summary: In "Create Branch" dialog, list "Available VCS Branches" from newest to oldest

fields.description:
BuildQueueUpdateListener dumps the whole queue and readds everything on four different events:

AllAgentsUpdatedEvent, AgentConfigurationUpdatedEvent, BuildRequirementUpdatedEvent and ElasticConfigUpdatedEvent.

Reconstructing the queue is a very costly operation.

For the BuildRequirementUpdatedEvent, the queue need not be reconstructed if the build in question isn't actually in the queue.
fields.summary: Change BuildQueueUpdateListener not reconstruct the queue on a BuildRequirementUpdatedEvent if the build isn't in the queue

fields.description:
We have many agents across the enterprise. It would be very useful if we could monitor all builds on a specific agent - or specific machine - or a collection of such. We group our builds by project type (mobile, desktop, O/S, etc.), which is nice, but we have agents that build plans that belong to different disciplines even though they are built by the same agent.

A machine should be able to report a dashboard or wallboard that shows the status of everything it builds. It just makes sense.
fields.summary: Allow dashboards and wallboards showing plan status for specific agent(s)

fields.description: Bamboo should be more flexible, allowing a Tasks result not to have any effect on the failing of the plan for situations where the Tasks can not all be finalising.
fields.summary: Bamboo should provide a way to ignore the success or failure of a Task

fields.description:
Bamboo creates metadata for each build and makes it visible on the Metadata tab in the build result.  Not all of this metadata is available for use in a build plan.  Only values listed as a Bamboo Property on [this page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Using+global%2C+plan+or+build-specific+variables] can be used in a Bamboo task.

Bamboo creates a file named build-number.txt in the build working directory.  This file contains data like this:
{noformat}
#Created by the Bamboo Continuous Integration Server
#Sat Aug 11 05:11:55 PDT 2012
build.number=343
build.timestamp="2012-08-11 05\:11\:55"
{noformat}

Could the metadata be added to this file or a similar file, say build-metadata.txt?

h3. Use Case
We have several different teams using Bamboo.  We have a shared ant script that each team includes in their build plan to perform a task.  One of the outputs of this script involves creating a file that uses the Build build key in the name and the SVN revision is stored in the content of the file.

Even though the SVN revision is available as Bamboo metadata, I cannot access it, so I need to use other means to obtain it.  Not a big deal, but it's too bad I need to write and maintain additional code to get this value when it is already available as metadata.  I can pass the build key on the plan command line, but this requires 6 or 7 different teams to manually update their task definitions to pass -Dbuild.key=${bamboo.buildKey}.

If these values were in a text file, I could load the file in ant and access the values without requiring changes to multiple build plans.  If new metadata is added in the future, I will already have access to it in my ant script without needing to modify build plans to pass it in.
fields.summary: Make all metadata available in file in build working directory

fields.description:
This was observed on BEAC in these builds:
- https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/JSTS-TALCNIGHTLY1-12
- https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/JSTS-ODCJ0-2

In both cases, new jobs in the plan were created by cloning an existing job, then modifying and saving it. Then, a branch build was executed. In that build, all changes made after cloning were ignored: the tasks in cloned jobs ran exactly as the original tasks from which they were cloned, ignoring any (saved) modifications to the plan made after cloning.

For example, see the following log files:
- https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/download/JSTS-ODCJ0-BUNDLEDPLUGINSN/build_logs/JSTS-ODCJ0-BUNDLEDPLUGINSN-2.log
- https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/download/JSTS-ODCJ0-JOB1/build_logs/JSTS-ODCJ0-JOB1-2.log

Both logs refer to test suite {{-Dtestng.suite=src/test/resources/testng-bundledplugins.xml}}. This is the suite of the original job (JSTS-ODCJ-BUNDLEDPLUGINSN). Yet, job JSTS-ODCJ-JOB1 (which was cloned from JSTS-ODCJ-BUNDLEDPLUGINSN) had been modified to use suite {{-Dtestng.suite=src/test/resources/testng-group1.xml}}:
!Selection_234.png|thumbnail!

That change was ignored in the build, so the jobs both ran the same suite.
fields.summary: Changes to tasks in cloned jobs are ignored.

fields.description: Bamboo experiences a general loss of functionality whenever there is "too many open files" errors. Such loss of functionality can be that Bamboo repository checkout failing. We have a knowledge article that prescribes how to overcome this error in this [page|https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=278695414&utm_source=SAC&utm_medium=hercules-issue-view&utm_content=356402]. It will be nice if Bamboo will be able to recover whenever there is a free file handles that are released without the need to restart Bamboo server.
fields.summary: Bamboo should be able to use free file handles after recovering from too many open files error without the need to restart

fields.description:
